Well, the only ones you'll be missing after beating the game once will require you to do the same♥♥♥♥♥♥listed above over and over again for hours. It won't be worth it. 												What an odd game! I'm really on the fence about whether or not to recommend it, so I've decided to recommend it but with a huge caveat.Firstly, this is the most mindless game I've ever played in my life, and I started playing video games in the 80s. Even mindless clickers involve the player more than this game does. There's literally nothing to do except for moving right and left and upgrading your stats. Combat and looting are automatic, and even your stats max out or become redundant at certain points, minimizing the value of upgrades. I found no obvious benefit to a speed in excess of 100, and while your critical stat allows you to keep dumping gold into upgrades, it goes no higher than 100%. I wasted a lot of loot before figuring that out. I also found no benefit to an excessive attack stat. There came a point where I just started dumping all my loot into defense, because that was the only stat that made any difference to me after the critical stat was maxed. This is not a game for someone who is looking for storyline or character development, because this game includes none of either. It's also not a game for someone looking for clear objectives or an endgame. At the time of this review, I've defeated the dragon 55 times, and the game hasn't finished. In fact, I don't think there is a finish line to this race. I've unlocked 100% of the achievements, and my stats at this point are: level 106; attk 180-359; crit 100; def 1376; and speed 126. I have no doubt that there is either no completion point to the game at all or that the ceiling is so ridiculously high as to call the sanity of anyone who would attempt it into question.The graphics could be a lot more clear and defined, especially since you're dealing with increased speeds, and the soundtrack is just average. There's not a single element that would motivate me to continue the game at this point, and I see zero replay value.That being said, the game does what it's meant to do very well. The controls are responsive, and no tutorial is necessary. It's an obvious choice for someone looking for an easy 100% game, but beyond that, there's not much else to say about this game. It offers no other challenge or benefit that I'm aware of. For me, it wasn't even entertaining. It was just something that I persevered through thinking that I was nearing the end.So my caveat is this. I recommend the game but only for casual gamers looking for a mindless game requiring absolutely no skill, or achievement hunters possessing a great deal of patience.

												TL;DR: A well-made but fairly pointless grinding game. Only recommended for achievement hunters so you at least get a trophy out of it.In a traditional RPG you usually start as a low-level character with little to no equipment and the only way to become more powerful is to complete quests kill monsters.Basically begin with a standard RPG. Take out quests and dialogues, reduce equipment to purchasable stats and reduce the combat to just damage-per-second and make it a side-scroller and you've got yourself Loot Hero. The gameplay consists of three parts: choosing a level, running left and right killing monsters and buying better stats at the towns in-between. There's also a short and pretty meaningless story: a terrible dragon has appeared and you, the hero, has to go and kill it to save the land.The first thing I noticed when I fired up the game was that there is no keyboard support whatsoever. The gameplay would be totally natural with keyboard, with the only keys being basically left and right (plus some extra keys for buying stuff at towns). I think this is a huge oversight from the developer, this being a PC game after all (even if you can play a version of it on the browser on various sites). After a minute I realized that mouse is functional: the guy runs towards the mouse cursor when click is held. This is fine but not as convenient as keyboard would have been.Finally I opted for a gamepad, which worked well. Furthermore it proved to be superior to the mouse: a bit more on the reason later. As the gameplay goes, the music and sounds are pretty good and running through and grinding monsters curiously feels quite satisfying. In addition to experience points and gold the monsters drop health and invulnerability potions, the latter of which makes you super fast and almost un-killable so you can easily grind through hordes of monsters with the music flowing consistently with the diamond tornado as the money gets sucked into your loot bag counter in the top-left corner.At first you have to play each level sequentially but after beating the first dragon you can skip any number of the subsequent levels to go even straight to the next dragon level. Usually you don't want to do that though, unless you have prepared: each level (called aptly Difficulty) is more difficult, i.e. contains stronger monsters than the previous one. It also provides a bit more experience (that is for levels) and gold (for buying better stats) than the previous one. There are different enemies to each level, but game mechanically they are identical, the only difference being visuals and their attack power and health.Thing is, it is so much more difficult to kill tougher monsters that you'll probably want to grind in a lower level until you can beat it consistently before going to the next one. Later on you can skip a few levels as you will develop an intuition of how powerful monsters you can kill easily. If you do a mistake, you are stuck in the level that is too difficult (well, at least I couldn't find a way to exit a level short of exiting the game). Then you can still grind, as diamonds drop even when hitting a monster once, so a boring left-right-left-right limbo can be issued right next to town for a slow but steady grind for better stats.You can heal (automatically) and buy stats at towns: there is attack and defence power, better critical strike chance and higher speed available for purchase. Critical strikes cap at 100% although for some reason you could still waste money on them afterwards. Speed seems to have a cap or I just wouldn't notice the slight change of pace after certain point. Then later on the only meaningful purchases were attack and defence power. Your stats get higher also when you level up the character.The speed upgrade caused some weird things when I got it at high values. I would run and then get stuck at some monsters (because I was not strong enough to kill them immediately), but the screen would continue onwards, leaving the hero and the monsters I was fighting out of the window. The monsters only spawn outside the screen, so then the hero would continuously fight monsters out of sight, usually dying eventually because if he could kill them, he'd pretty much run right through them and not be left behind. This is where I pulled the controller out: with mouse I can't retreat the other way because I can't get the cursor to the other side of the hero who is outside the screen. With gamepad I could at least do that.A minor bug occurred sometimes when the high speed also made me run straight past the boss monster, presumably because he was not spawned yet as the character ran past him.By the way, dying is of little consequence: you can immediately revive and continue grinding. You just lose a bit of experience and gold when that happens. It was not too much but enough to make me cautious.4.5 hours of grinding later I had 100% completed the game achievement-wise (I will still have to idle a bit for cards). I had defeated 38 dragons and thus saved 38 miners. The miners provide gold for you when you're idle, pretty pointless as there's a hard cap of 99999 gold. Frankly, the game was pretty boring. I get the parody of reducing the present-day RPGs to their bare bones of gold and experience grinding but the notion isn't worth a whole game. That said, it's mere 3 €: if you fancy getting a fairly easy 100%, it might be worth it at least when it's on sale. If you can manage, play it while watching a movie or similar. The rest of you: go play something better.

												Recommended for select gamers.This game is not for everyone, but if you like trying out experimental game concepts and ideas there is a gem here to be had.  If, however, you are looking for a fully fleshed out game with lots of immersion, choices, quests, story or depth then this game is probably one to pass by.Perhaps the king of casual gamers, there is some satisfaction in the mindless left, right, left action which results in the demise of hordes and hordes of baddies.  And . . . that's it, that's the whole game.  Move your mouse to the left of the screen your hero moves left, move it to the right and he moves right.  Stop on screen at a shop and you can tweek a few stats: attack, crit, armor and speed.  You play through ten levels each with a "boss" (more on that later) at the end, and after the tenth level is completed the difficulty slightly increases and you replay through all the same levels over again.  This continues on until you get bored and stop playing, or for many, until you reach level 100 and get the last Steam achievement.Why this works:  Mindless fun can be fun!  Plus you do get to plow through hordes and hordes of enemies in mere seconds.  And you can watch TV while you play and only glance back at the computer from time to time while grinding to that level 100.However, what doesn't really work is that there isn't any real game after that.  It really feels like a good first level for a much grander game, but it just stops there and then repeats itself.  Even with the ability to up skills I soon discovered that I really only had to up my armor skill to be able to beat any levels that momentarily detered me.  Also, bosses were pointless.  They aren't stronger than the other monsters in the level, at least not by enough of a margin to be noticable, so if you can sail through the level, the boss will be a one hit kill.  Plus there were a few balancing issues I came across; either I could sail through the level without a hitch including the boss, or I was beaten by the first three monsters I encounted.  There were no inbetween challenging levels.  I could either beat the level outright, or I repeatedly died and had to go out and replay the previous level until I had accrued enough gold to buy enough armor to sail through the next one.Then the main trouble I had while trying to level my hero up to 100 was that the levels never got any longer.  So, most levels are easy to beat in about 15 to 20 seconds, but you need to really grind the experience to level up your knight, meaning there were many times when I inadvertently finished a level instead of swinging back and forth to gain experience for my guy.  And finishing a level in only a matter of seconds means that the load times to go back to the main menu and then back into the levels seem much much longer than they actually are.  It would have been really helpful to lengthen the levels as they got "harder" then to just have them be exactly the same every time.I should mention that everytime you beat the 10th level boss you save a miner who then goes and mines gold for you, apparently even when you are not playing the game.  While this could have been a charming aspect of the game it actual was 100% pointless.  Most people will achieve 80% of the achievements in the first hour and then it becomes a grind fest for the last 2 leveling up achievements which really only take 2 or 3 more hours.  So, having a person mine gold while you don't have the game running isn't neccessary as you will probably play through the whole game in your first session.  Also, your gold maxes out at something like 999,999 or so which really only takes 40 to 60 seconds to accrue while playing in game, so the slow pecking away the miners do to get you 20,000 gold after 10 mins isn't even noticable, or needed.  Perhaps some other system of freeing different townsfolk to collect would have been a better end-of-level reward.All in all, I really did have fun playing this game, but its limitations means it really is for the experimental gamer.  If the previous description of the game did not deter you, then by all means I encourage you to purchase this game and try it out for yourself, because it really has a unique game design to it, but just know ahead of time that it isn't going to give you much more than that.

When enemies are defeated they drop gold which can be spent on upgrades to Attack, Defence, Critical hit Chance or Speed however only attack or defence are of any use, you also gain experience points which will eventually level your character which gives pitiful bonuses to these stats in comparison to the bought upgrades.The enemies do nothing to stop your progress other than act as a blockade and you can stand next to them without fear of been attacked or been pushed back, they also almost immediately respawn once you pass an area so you can grind back and forth through the same line without having to progress in the level.While there is minor story elements at the beginning the ending is little more that "A winner is you" before shunting you back to the menu and increasing the level of all the monsters and levels.You do gain a single miner each time who earns you gold while your not playing but because of the small gold cap you soon can earn the maximum amount of gold in seconds at the higher levels.As I say repeatedly during the review I love the artwork and this could of been made into a nifty little rogue light or platform RPG but if you need something to kill ten minutes Loot Hero DX is ideal but its not much use for anything else.

												I really want to like this game: it has really neat pixel graphics, lots of critters to kill, keeps stats, and has achievements and trading cards. But, the reality is that the gameplay gets boring after the first three minutes. Even the added concept of releasing miners to collect gold for you after every successful run through all levels fails, because it's just accelerating a timer event...it doesn't add to the gameplay at all. In the end, all you do is collect enough treasure and XP to buff your character, who kills the baddies by -- literally -- running into them. There is no learning tactics for combat or developing strategies by buffing your character a specific way. You just level up your stats evenly as you collect loot, enough that you don't watch your health bar go down much at all while you're running back and forth, grind away until you start taking damage as you continue through the levels, and then rinse and repeat. Gameplay does not change on any levels, nor do you treat any of the creatures differently...you just run through them.I did play long enough to get 100% achievements (and collect all trading cards), which is easy except for the final one of leveling up to level 100. That's a long grind, but I basically did it while in boring, listen-in virtual meetings for work since the game requires little to no brain power and I had almost zero chance of being distracted enough to get into trouble.  :DTLDR; this game is a left-mouse-button simulator, and it succeeds in that regard. Where it does not succeed is in being interesting or, consequently, fun. Only bother if you're an achievement hunter looking for an easy 100% or a hardcore card collector, and even in that case you should look to get it as part of a bundle or epic sale.

												OVERVIEWKill baddies with a few clicks of your mouse...And a lot of just holding down the LMB. :D That's Loot Hero DX in a nutshell. You can play it for free, or play this slightly updated version for a few bucks. Is it worth it? Let's see.PROS+ Decent graphics.+ Good music and sound.+ Cheap (as it should be).+ Trading cards.+ Difficulty is scaled reasonably well.+ Relatively amusing, and great for when you don't feel like putting any effort into a game.+ Miner system is nice.CONS- Too repetitive. A little design finesse could have helped a lot here - adding a bit more story, some randomness, etc. - The FPS rate drops pretty badly later in the game. It's also a bit slow loading in general.- You have to go to the main menu to exit the game.- Slightly glitchy; e.g., sometimes when you go to exit, you'll click, and "Yes", "No" will be left floating over the main menu, and it didn't really exit. It's also had issues where it didn't update the run speed properly. Also, muting the sound still allows this weird clicking noise to occur occasionally, just like normal; plus, the noise when you get knocked out remains present. Code is sometimes present at the end on screen when you beat the last boss.- You can't upgrade critical past 100%, but it will still take your money.- It would be nice if you could have it where it just goes from level-to-level instead of having to leave the level and selecting a new one. An infinite mode would also be a nice touch, where it just runs level-to-level in a seamless fashion - one big level that repeats over and over. It would make grinding for level 100 easier.- Your hero seems to get stuck sometimes; like he slams into the same enemy over and over, and you can't see him on the screen.- There shouldn't be a gold cap.- You should be able to mute sound without adjusting the levels.CONCLUSIONIt's cheap, decent, mindless fun, you get trading cards, and you're supporting an indie developer. It will give a few hours of fun over a period of time of your choosing, and seems like something that would be fun to come back to every now and then for some easy-as-heck victory. To me, that's worth it - and if you can get it on sale, even more so.Thanks for reading my review; I hope it was helpful. Have a great day, and Godspeed!

												Like other "incremental games", this seeks to allow you to pour hours of your time grinding away levels to upgrade your character in order to defeat endless waves of enemies and bosses with no end in sight. How it actually falls short of this goal in such a simple genre is incredible, really.As some reviews here have said, the game is simply too easy. You hit the end goal far too quickly, and your goal then becomes a mission to collect all of the achievements. I was able to collect all of the achievements the game had to offer in a few hours time... making continuous play pointless, but that's not entirely why.I don't think the game developers actually expect people to play this game for longer than an hour. You VERY QUICKLY hit a point in the game where your levels no longer go up visually, as though they didn't think a counter that works was necessary. Like saying "Nobody is going to max this skill, so who cares?", but you should care... because you can max the skill in under 30 minutes.The levels don't have enough variety either. I mean you can't expect much from these incremental games as it is, but when you start reading "you've defeated the dragon 42 times", being the end-boss, it's really depressing.There also comes a point where you gain so much coin from each level run, that you can honestly beat the final boss, load the next difficulty tier, and then jump straight to the end boss and kill it again... and again... The more you play, the easier it gets, which is typically the opposite of what these games are supposed to be about. You gain exponentially more coin which means you can upgrade exponentially faster. There is a COIN MAX of 99,999 and each upgrade costs 9,999 and will never cost more, no matter how much you've upgraded them. Again, they don't expect that you're going to play this game very long, so why increment higher than 9,999?? Yeah.... When you can gain 9,999 coins from hitting a mere few enemies, it's not hard to upgrade yourself beyond the capacity of the game.While the game is too easy and runs out of runway too early, there are also certain things that annoy me after the 40th time too. Once I've beaten the dragon boss 40 times, you can stop SLOWLY giving me the message about the increase in difficulty and you can stop SLOWLY showing me that I've unlocked another miner, and you can stop showing me that same loading screen to take me to the levels because I'm just trying to get through it so I can jump to the final boss again and beat him in 5 seconds flat.The miners... I reminded myself of these useless things. In the early game, once you beat it you unlock a coin miner which can, quite obviously, mine coins for you while you're away. The more you unlock, the more coins you unlock. Remember the coin issues I talked about earlier though... when you're making the max 99,999 coins within a few minutes, what exactly is the point of having several dozen miners also generating a max 99,999 coins for you?? Yay I can do about 20 upgrades to my defence and get through the end boss 5 more times for ABSOLUTELY NO REASON!And this is my last point: With other incremental games, they're difficult enough that you feel like if you sit there grinding, ultimately you'll reach an end result that is awe inspiring. You can unlock heroes to help your DPS, you can "prestige" your character to reset all levels and grind from scratch, unlocking skills as rewards for hours of play, but with this game there's no point! You hit the end within the first half hour, and you can reach the point of no more level gain within the first hour, and you can collect every single achievement (the hardest being level 100) within a few hours of play leaving there absolutely zero reason to keep going. You're as strong as you ever need to be, and you can safely uninstall the game never to look back.Of course it's a pretty cheap game on Steam, but this should seriously be a free app.... It's not worth the sale price and CERTAINLY not worth a full pricing.

Meaning kill the dragon in the last level. But the draw I suppose is that there is this old saying the kids are saying“this is where the real Loot Hero DX begins”. Each time you kill the dragon you save a little charmander looking thing and he starts work in the mines getting more and more gold. Even when the game is off. Money of course is the main resource in the game. Allowing you to upgrade attack, chance of crit, defense and speed. So, as you are slaying beasts by pressing left or right but mostly right; you go real fast and then you go even faster. If you do happen to die you are just sent back the shop when you can upgrade (which are about every couple of inches on every stage) The only penalty for dying is losing a very small amount of XP and a bit of loot that hasn't been picked up yet. IntroductionLoot Hero DX was orginally for android devices, with the way it plays the game is obviously ported over from mobile almost straight to Steam and then sold at a price after they add some other features to the game in the Steam version. This game is very grindy, so if you don't like games where it requires you to grind for money and exp then you're not going to like this game.GameplayFirst thing I think that most people will want to know after reading the introduction of this review is what's the difference between Loot Hero DX on Steam, and the free to play version called Loot Hero. According to the developer, the main purpose of putting it on steam and putting a price on it is the graphical side of the game, full screen 60 fps (the android version consists of small window with 30fps) better effects and a "facelift." I'm not really sure what the developer meant by a "facelift" but they have added a few more levels and a miner thing whereby you save a miner everytime you kill a dragon and they will collect gold for you over time. Now that's out of the way, I will briefly explain the way that this game is played. Basically there has been a dragon that has taken over the lands and you, the hero, have to kill it. You will be required to go through a few levels before getting to the dragon, whilst upgrading 4 main things a hero needs. Attack, Critical, Defense and Speed. After killing the dragon once, takes maybe 30 minutes or so you now have to do it again, but on a harder difficulty. This is basically the whole game. What are my thoughts? The game to begin with was fun, collecting exp, leveling up, upgrading my items over time and just generally running into enemies by killing them. After beating the dragon the first time, it did really restrict the replay value of the game a bit. But, I pushed on to defeat the dragon once again. 3 hours passed, I had totally lost interest in this game. It becomes a drag of constant leveling up and upgrading your items until you can kill the dragon over and over again. The game has some really great music when you are killing enmeies, and the slightly destructable enviroment was rather nice. But as you played more, and came back to the same levels they got boring, and I just felt no need to play through the game anymore.Pros+ Fun at first to play+ Nice music+ Killing enemies sometimes destorys enviroment+ Trading cards & AchievementsCons- Limited replay value- Constantly going through the same levels gets boring rather quicklyResult / Final thoughtsAlthough I have stopped playing the game because of it's limited replay value and repetitive gameplay, I still recommened this game. The reason for that is because the game is rather cheap, and the first few times playing the game I really enjoyed it. But now I won't be able to enjoy it because of the constant grind and repetitive gameplay.Rating: 7.5/10For more reviews on a wide range of games, go and follow Lot's O Giveaway's curator group here.

												I actually really like this game.I've always had a softspot for Pixel art, the Loot Hero DX ticks all the boxes. It's rather simple though, you run from side to side impaling enemies with your lance, collect the loot they drop, upgrade your items and speed and repeat. You do this over and over through different areas, and monsters until you finally reach the dragon and dispatch him.Afterwards the game restarts and you continue on, with the same game, but more difficult each time. Killing the dragon does rescue a single miner though and it unlocks the mine. They'll slowly collect loot for you, but honestly it's not needed. As shown in the second half of my little video, you can become utterly god-like and just demolish everything.Now the game does get extremely repetitive, unless you simply can't get enough, or you need all the achievements available; but I still enjoy it. The music and art is lovely, and I do hope the developer will expand on the game and later turn it into a platformer/sidescrolling adventure game. I would really enjoy it.As it stands, is it worth the asking price? I personally think so. It's great for bouts of fun, and I couldn't help but giggle to myself as I essentially turned into an armour wearing jousting sonic of death.

pixel-styled clicker with alot of fun, achievements and content.In this game you fight against hordes of enemies and try to improve your loot hero to the max ( if that exists at least ).You come across several taverns which offer you upgrades for your loot hero, you can upgrade your attack, crictical hit chance, defence and your movement speed.I prefered to upgrade my critical chance alot in addition with a good defence.It worked out greatly and i finished the game once, after you finish your game ( when you slayed the dragon at the latest world ) you will start all over again but your enemies are way stronger and so are your rewards aswell, you will also gain 1 miner with every completition of the game.The miners will gather gold for you while you away and you can collect when you're back in the game, you can use the gold you collected to upgrade your loot hero with the mentioned upgradeable perks.Let's continue to the ratings:~~~~ Positive Points ~~~~ Great innovative gameplay Great pixel design A good bunch of achievements Trading cards support Good controls, nothing to mention.~~~~ Negative points ~~~~ Resolution could have been higher, but not really much an issue It's always nice to have a bigger amount of achievements, like 100 or 200.Summary:There is nothing to rant based on gameplay, controls or nice additions like achievements and trading cards, and that's why this is a good game, a clicker game yes, but a really good clicker game.I recommend you all to buy this game if you liked Plantera, keep in mind that it is different than games like Clicker 												5/10Decent fun, but incredibly repetitive. Recommended, but if you don't like repetition, stay away.Loot Hero DX is a mobile-to-PC port that isn't free but also has no in-game purchases. The premise is simple: move right, defeat a boss in the end, move to the next level. Your character auto-attacks enemies on the way and you use your gold to purchase upgrades. Between each "wave" of enemies there's a house/building where you recover your HP and can buy upgrades. Once the game is finished, you free a miner who will generate gold passively for you and move on to the next difficulty. This goes on endlessly - there is no limit to how far you can go on the game as there's always the next difficulty level.At first, the game is quite fun as you start out slow and progress through, buying upgrades, making your character stronger, faster and more resilient. However, further on as you've already finished the game a few times, the game loses a lot of its value and becomes a grindfest. The levels are the same over and over so there isn't anything new to work for too, so it's just replaying the same game over and over. Eventually you'll have reached max speed for your character and as you continue to upgrade your character, you'll find yourself finishing entire levels in less than 5 seconds, until you hit a difficulty barrier which then forces you to grind for a while to buy more upgrades, then continue to push through.And specially, if you're looking to get all achievements in the game, prepare for a lot - a LOT - of grinding.Overall, fun game but loses its value very quickly.
